stem: A 12-year-old oncology client with severe immunosuppression received a non-irradiated unit of whole blood 10 days ago. The client now presents with a diffuse maculopapular rash and jaundice. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two actions the nurse should take, and two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: The client is experiencing acute multiorgan system failure 10 days post-transfusion. The client presents with a diffuse maculopapular rash and jaundice.
Background: The client has Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) and is receiving high-dose chemotherapy, resulting in severe immunosuppression. A non-irradiated unit of whole blood was administered 10 days ago.
Assessment: The client exhibits widespread skin peeling (desquamation), severe diarrhea, elevated liver enzymes (AST 342, ALT 410), and pancytopenia (ANC 150/mm³). Vital signs indicate septic-like shock (BP 92/58, HR 132, RR 24, T 103.8°F).
Recommendation: A biopsy and bone marrow check are recommended to evaluate for Transfusion-Associated Graft vs. Host Disease (TA-GVHD). Ensure all future blood products are irradiated.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: BP 92/58, HR 132, RR 24, T 103.8°F. Client is in septic-like shock.

actionOptions.text: Ensure all future blood products are irradiated
Administer immunosuppressants and supportive fluid therapy
Increase the IV rate of blood

parameterOptions.text: Liver function tests and bilirubin levels

rationale.correct: The client is most likely experiencing Transfusion-Associated Graft vs. Host Disease (TA-GVHD) (c2). TA-GVHD is a rare but severe complication that occurs when donor T-lymphocytes attack the immunocompromised host's tissues, particularly the skin, liver, and bone marrow. This typically manifests 1-2 weeks post-transfusion. The hallmark signs include a diffuse maculopapular rash, elevated liver enzymes leading to jaundice, and severe bone marrow suppression (pancytopenia). The priority nursing actions are to ensure all future blood products are irradiated (a1) to neutralize donor lymphocytes and to administer immunosuppressants and supportive fluid therapy (a2) to mitigate the immune response and manage symptoms. Key parameters to monitor include serial CBC with differential (p1) to assess bone marrow function and liver function tests and bilirubin levels (p2) to evaluate liver involvement.
clinicalPearls: TA-GVHD has a high mortality rate (>90%) due to its devastating effect on the bone marrow.
Irradiation of blood products is the primary prevention strategy, as it neutralizes donor lymphocytes.
Consider TA-GVHD in immunocompromised patients who develop a rash, liver dysfunction, and pancytopenia 1-2 weeks after a blood transfusion.

questionTrap.trap: Misinterpreting the rash as an allergic reaction to the transfusion.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Allergic reactions typically occur during or immediately after the transfusion. TA-GVHD manifests days to weeks later and involves multiple organ systems, including the liver and bone marrow.

mnemonic.title: TA-GVHD
mnemonic.expansion: TA-GVHD: Transfusion Associated - Generalized rash, Vital organs (liver) fail, Hematologic (marrow) failure, Death.
